awd_titl_txt: Long Term Urban Change in Response to Social Collapse
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the National Science Foundation, Dr. Sarah Clayton and colleagues will examine how the collapse of centralized states influences subsequent processes of urban growth and the development of new forms of government. This project employs remote sensing and archaeological methods to investigate the spatial, demographic, and political characteristics of cities that formed in the wake of violent conflict and large-scale migration. Results of this research will advance knowledge of successful strategies of civic planning and polity building among second-generation, or "post-collapse" societies. This project contributes to scholarship concerning the evolution of urban landscapes, modes of governance, and the ways in which the legacies of failed states impact these developments. Such legacies may include concepts of leadership, identity, memories of historical events, and the physical consequences of state-related systems of resource management, transportation, or militarization on surrounding landscapes. This project provides training opportunities for students and enhances international scholarly collaboration through its involvement of researchers from Mexico. The professional advancement of women in STEM fields is supported through the involvement of female students and colleagues in the research. The project makes a positive impact on the local community by working to promote awareness and the preservation of archaeological remains. 

This research will be carried out at a large pre-Columbian settlement in central Mexico which experienced rapid growth in conjunction with a neighboring polity's decline. As such it provides an important case study for examining strategies of political regeneration and urban planning. Unlike many of its contemporaries, the site prospered following its neighbor's collapse, and within a century had grown from a village of a few hundred people to a city of several thousand, featuring monumental architecture and social stratification. This growth resulted in part from the absorption of migrants, possibly including refugees. This project examines the spatial organization of their new city, the size of its population, and the ways in which the construction of monuments, temples, and public spaces promoted local strategies of leadership. This research employs a program of excavation and remote sensing methods, including aerial photography by drone; radar; and gradient magnetic and electrical resistivity survey to examine the spatial characteristics of the settlement and to estimate the size of the population. The project is methodologically innovative in its application of remote sensing to an extensive area for the purposes of examining urban planning and polity building.

por.por_cntn:
This project combined archaeological and remote sensing methods to examine the responses of local communities to broader changes associated with the decline of regional states. The overarching objective of the work was to understand the ways in which new communities develop under conditions of political instability. To investigate these issues, a multi-year program of field research was undertaken at the archaeological site of Chicoloapan, in the southern Basin of Mexico. This settlement grew rapidly in the wake of the political collapse and depopulation of Teotihuacan, which had been the capital of a powerful state and the largest city of its time (~1–550 CE) in the Americas. Between 550 and 660 CE, Chicoloapan expanded from a village of a few hundred people to a town of several thousand, featuring monumental architecture, residential structures, and landscape modifications related to agriculture. The circumstances of its growth and subsequent longevity, as a settlement that was inhabited for about three centuries, make it a strategic case study for examining processes of community building and political restructuring. 

An interdisciplinary approach including archaeology, geophysics, and environmental science was applied in order to investigate Chicoloapan’s development and to reconstruct the everyday practices and strategies that contributed to its persistence. Magnetic survey and electrical resistivity were used to locate buried archaeological features across large portions of the settlement, covering a total area of 50,000 m2.  This work resulted in the identification of diverse architectural structures and activity areas, including residential complexes and various forms of monumental architecture. Archaeological excavations, termed ‘operations,’ were conducted in conjunction with geophysical studies to generate detailed information about residential and civic-ceremonial architecture and associated contexts of activity. In all, 16 operations were completed by the project. Materials from excavated contexts, including ceramic and lithic artifacts, faunal and botanical remains, and carbon samples for radiocarbon dating, were analyzed to investigate local domestic practices and communal activities.  

This research resulted in three significant outcomes that advance knowledge of community formation and resilience in the region. First, the project generated detailed information about residential practices and the social organization of domestic groups. Prospection combined with drone photography made it possible to identify and estimate the dimensions of large architectural complexes that were likely inhabited by multi-household residential groups. Structures of this kind were not previously known in the southern Basin of Mexico but were present at Teotihuacan, suggesting that this way of living at Chicoloapan reflects a dimension of continuity with long-established residential patterns in the region. In the context of a post-collapse settlement, such a practice may also have fostered forms of social and economic cooperation that were vital to the long-term stability of the community.

Second, magnetic survey yielded information about diverse forms of monumental architecture, some of which have not been previously documented in this area. In addition to pyramidal temple structures, which are visible from the ground surface, two buried structures were identified that measure approximately 500 m2 in area and are delimited by thick, stone walls. Excavations focusing on one of these structures indicate that it was an enclosed patio, evidently lacking interior walls but surrounded on all four sides by broad, low walls that may have served as elevated walkways. This was a large enough space to accommodate significant numbers of people and may have functioned as a venue for social events or the exchange of goods. Integrative structures such as these likely played a significant role in promoting a sense of community among residents of the settlement, particularly during its initial period of growth.  

Finally, the analysis of archaeological materials from a variety of excavated contexts has produced significant information about local practices and material culture through time. Artifacts from the site were associated with local foodways, craft production, domestic ritual, and activities carried out in civic-ceremonial contexts, such as temples. Studies of these objects aid in understanding the adoption of new practices as well as the continuation of previously established practices within the region. More than 30,000 artifacts have been analyzed by the project, including fragments of pottery, figurines, incense burners, musical instruments, ground stone tools, and obsidian knives, darts, and blades. The datasets resulting from these analyses represent the most extensive and detailed sources of information about material culture in the southern Basin of Mexico after the decline of the former state. Comparison with artifact assemblages from other sites in the region further contributes to knowledge of interaction among diverse groups, patterns of migration, and the reorganization of exchange networks.
